questions.questionText: What forces do you see acting on the bucket in this picture?

rubric.exceeds: Student identifies multiple forces (gravity pulling down, hydraulic push upward, and arm support) with accurate descriptions of how each force acts on the bucket.
rubric.meets: Student identifies at least two forces acting on the bucket, such as gravity and the push from the hydraulic arm, with generally accurate descriptions.
rubric.approaching: Student identifies one force acting on the bucket or mentions two forces with vague or partially inaccurate descriptions of how they work.
rubric.beginning: Student attempts to name a force but provides minimal detail or shows confusion about what forces are present.

questions.questionText: If the backhoe stopped pushing with its hydraulic arm, what would happen to the bucket? Why?

rubric.exceeds: Student predicts the bucket would fall and explains that gravity pulls objects down when the upward force from the hydraulic arm is removed, creating an unbalanced force.
rubric.meets: Student predicts the bucket would fall and provides a reasonable explanation involving gravity or loss of the supporting force from the hydraulic arm.
rubric.approaching: Student predicts the bucket would fall but provides an incomplete or partially unclear explanation of why this would happen.
rubric.beginning: Student makes a prediction about what would happen but offers no explanation or provides an inaccurate reason.

questions.questionText: Why do you think the backhoe has such a long arm instead of a short, stubby arm?

rubric.exceeds: Student explains that the long arm increases leverage or mechanical advantage, allowing the backhoe to lift heavy objects and reach farther distances than a short arm could achieve.
rubric.meets: Student explains that the long arm helps the backhoe lift heavier things or reach farther, showing understanding of the practical advantage.
rubric.approaching: Student suggests the long arm helps with lifting or reaching but provides incomplete reasoning or uses imprecise language to explain the benefit.
rubric.beginning: Student attempts an answer but shows minimal understanding, such as simply stating the arm is long without explaining why that matters.

questions.questionText: Compare lifting a heavy rock with your hands versus using the backhoe. How are the forces different?

rubric.exceeds: Student explains that the backhoe uses a hydraulic engine to create a much larger upward force than human muscles can produce, making it possible to lift objects that would be impossible by hand.
rubric.meets: Student identifies that the backhoe produces a greater force than human hands and explains this difference helps lift heavier objects.
rubric.approaching: Student notes that the backhoe is stronger or can lift heavier things but provides incomplete explanation of how the forces are different.
rubric.beginning: Student attempts a comparison but offers minimal detail or shows unclear understanding of how the forces differ between human strength and machine power.
